b2cc5f49d5f892dbf022c62ec48f4e4bd95cf7cd.commitMessage:
Rename MethodTestDescriptor to TestMethodTestDescriptor

This commit renames MethodTestDescriptor in order to align with the
naming convention for other test descriptors in Jupiter that pertain
to methods.

bef03b5ce4c2385a99b13ac1a3354ac2ca8acc96.commitMessage:
Introduce getRequired*() methods in the ExtensionContext API

This commit introduces new getRequiredTestClass(),
getRequiredTestInstance(), and getRequiredTestMethod() convenience
methods in the ExtensionContext API which provide extension authors
shortcuts for retrieving the test class, test instance, and test method
in use cases for which such elements are required to be present.

Issue: #913

9eacc9c2d51557bffa003ca24fa125b8cbe69bbb.commitMessage:
Convert MethodInvoker to generic ExecutableInvoker

Prior to this commit, MethodInvoker was limited to method invocations.
With the recent generalization of the ParameterResolver API, it is now
possible to convert MethodInvoker to a generic ExecutableInvoker that
can be applied to constructors or methods, serving as a building block
for possible constructor injection support.

This commit converts MethodInvoker to a generic ExecutableInvoker that
can be used to invoke both methods and constructors with dynamic
parameter resolution via registered ParameterResolvers.

Specifically, this commit includes the following changes.

 - Renamed MethodInvoker to ExecutableInvoker
 - Refactored ExecutableInvoker to support parameter resolution for any
   java.lang.reflect.Executable
 - Introduced newInstance(Constructor<T>, Object...) in ReflectionUtils
 - Introduced invoke(Constructor), invoke(Method), and
   invoke(Method, Object) in ExecutableInvoker
 - Removed MethodInvocationContext and MethodInvocationContextFactory
 - Removed ConstructorInvoker proof of concept

Issue: #267

a409b27b1fca748a504a8bbcf7a914eeadeebdab.commitMessage:
Introduce getTest[Class|Method]() in TestInfo & ExtensionContext

This commit introduces Optional<Class<?>> getTestClass() and
Optional<Method> getTestMethod() methods in TestInfo and
ExtensionContext.

The existing `Class<?> getTestClass()` method in ExtensionContext has
simply been replaced, and the existing `Method getTestMethod()` method
in TestExtensionContext has been removed.

Issue: #153

a1eb11673e2b7e69bc0c4c2f5c5b81cf572dfeab.commitMessage:
Mask checked exceptions as unchecked exceptions in ReflectionUtils

Prior to this commit, ReflectionUtils.handleException() wrapped checked
exceptions in a TargetExceptionWrapper (a subclass of RuntimeException).
This forced clients of ReflectionUtils to manually handle unwrapping of
checked exceptions.

This commit introduces a new throwAsRuntimeException() method in
ReflectionUtils which uses a reflective hack (based on generics and type
erasure) that tricks the Java compiler into believing that the thrown
exception is an unchecked exception. This approach allows both checked
and unchecked exceptions to transparently propagate up the call stack
without forcing callers to explicitly handle checked exceptions. In
addition, this approach avoids the need to wrap/unwrap checked
exceptions via the TargetExceptionWrapper.

Furthermore, this commit refactors exception handling code within the
JUnit 5 engine to use the newly introduced ThrowableCollector API for
consistent, simplified tracking of exceptions.

Issue: #64

------------------------------------------------------------------------
On behalf of the community, the JUnit Lambda Team thanks
Samuraism, Inc. (http://samuraism.com/) for supporting the
JUnit crowdfunding campaign!
------------------------------------------------------------------------

Mask checked exceptions as unchecked exceptions in ReflectionUtils

Prior to this commit, ReflectionUtils.handleException() wrapped checked
exceptions in a TargetExceptionWrapper (a subclass of RuntimeException).
This forced clients of ReflectionUtils to manually handle unwrapping of
checked exceptions.

This commit introduces a new throwAsRuntimeException() method in
ReflectionUtils which uses a reflective hack (based on generics and type
erasure) that tricks the Java compiler into believing that the thrown
exception is an unchecked exception. This approach allows both checked
and unchecked exceptions to transparently propagate up the call stack
without forcing callers to explicitly handle checked exceptions. In
addition, this approach avoids the need to wrap/unwrap checked
exceptions via the TargetExceptionWrapper.

Furthermore, this commit refactors exception handling code within the
JUnit 5 engine to use the newly introduced ThrowableCollector API for
consistent, simplified tracking of exceptions.
